snippet.title: Sister grieves US Marine killed in Osprey crash off Queensland
snippet.content:
The family of one of three Marines killed in an aircraft accident off the coast of Queensland has asked for prayers for their lost loved one. Corporal Nathan Ordway from Wichita, Kansas, was onboard the MV-22 Osprey that crashed as it attempted to land on the USS Green Bay about 4pm Saturday, about 30km from Shoalwater Bay military training area. It's believe the controversial tilt rotor aircraft slammed into the flight deck and slid into the Coral Sea. Twenty-three of the 26 Marines onboard were rescued, but three could not be saved. Cpl Ordway's family have confirmed he is among the missing Marines. His sister took to the 31st Marine Expeditionary Unit's Facebook page to ask people to "please pray for my brother". Family friend Heidi Peltzer also asked for people to "please pray for his life, his safety and comfort for the family", in a social media post.
Related Articles
The families of all three missing Marines have been notified. Australian Navy resources are en route to the accident site to assist with locating and recovering the bodies. Navy survey vessel HMAS Melville is traveling from Cairns, and a clearance dive team is flying into the Shoalwater Bay Area. Defence Minister Marise Payne warned it could take some to recover the bodies. "These recovery operations are complex in nature and are affected by a range of factors including weather conditions, water depth, debris and water current," she said. It's believed the water depth at the crash site is about 50m. Australian Defence Force officials have also offered to assist in the investigation into the crash. Many of the 23 rescued service personnel are being treat on the navy amphibious warship the USS Bonhomme Richard. The most seriously injured person was flown to Rockhampton Base Hospital suffering extensive injuries including a broken leg. The 36-year-old Marine was taken to Brisbane overnight for specialist care. (C) Nine Digital Pty Ltd 2017
